comment_1: OK kids. This is a song simply about living on a tour bus. We in the biz refer to long bus rides as a "submarine ride." The first tour busses were the old school busses. The phrase "many more of them live next door."is a referal to the crew bus. Taken in this pretext it's simply a song about life on the road. Most songs like this are taken from real life situations and are written from the perspective of everyday occurances. Most musicians live in the moment and are not as introspective as one would assume. Look for the simplistic and you will find most of the meanings to songs are just that, simple.

A lot of people are saying this song doesn't have a meaning... Well I think it does, actually. Its just you need some background information to understand it. But hey, I might be wrong. 

I heard somewhere that the military used to use yellow submarines for target practice, they painted it yellow because it was easier to see against the blue or green water. So the yellow submarines were just target practice that ended up getting hit and ruined all the time. 

If they DID base the song off that bit of information, then the song makes a lot more sense, to me... Its kinda a sad song, if its true... But it doesn't sound sad, so maybe the yellow submarine thing is just a coincidence.

here they are making us realise that material things mean nothing, just the simplistic things that make life such as the sky and the sea.

'many more them live next door' meaning they cant get to them, they feel isolated from there friends even although they are so close.

comment_145: Yellow Submarine-I read the first page of the 2002 entries (from what I've seen of the dates, this appears to be when this website came into existence).  Someone said that this song means to them that The Beatles can get away with making a silly song and it will be a hit.  Others said itâs about drugs and some said it means childhood and growing up.  For me, the song means, that is, what I think of when I hear it is that The Beatles can get away with a silly song (esp., having Ringo sing it gives it that silly, we don't take ourselves too serious attitude) and it will somehow make a lasting impression on their listening public.  Personally, I think the song itself is awful.  But whatâs so amazing is that somehow the Beatles are so damn charming, so damn clever and inventive and creative and just so damn good that a song as bad as this becomes one instantly recognizable.  It goes from bad and forgettable to a curiosity that is almost listenable.  It brings forth quite a bizarre imagery set and Iâm taken somewhere even if I donât know where.  For some itâs to a place in which they want to impale things.  But for most of us, itâs a better placeâchildhood, the sea and its mystery, an adventure or to thoughts about what in the hell were they actually thinking with this one?  And to boot, they make a movie with its title.  Drugs?  Indubitably!  The English were so conservative, âprim and properâ I think they call it.  The Beatles (esp., John) were so irreverent, so cheeky, so New Britain, that they challenged everything holding them back.  This creative and unbounded energy created songs/movies Help!, A Hard Dayâs Night, and Yellow Submarine.  The last of which was helped in no small part by the psychedelic drug culture of the 60âs. This creativity (with and without drugs) didnât come out all that great in their movies, but their songs trump all.  And this song represents for me all of these disparate elements coming together into a silly but poignant sign of  where The Beatles came from and played a fundamental and integral part in shaping music both silly and profound.

When Lennon describes his first trip on LSD, he talks about how George's house felt like a submarine. This song refers to all of their first trip and how high they all were. It is obvious if you think about it:

Yellow submarine = literally George's house but has a deeper connotation of their new lifestyle with hard drugs
comment_182:
I think saying this song is simple and childish is a massive cop-out. First of all, very few people were constructing songs with sound effects in 1966, and they certainly were not reaching as many people that the Beatles were. Second of all, the melody to the verse and chorus are insanely catchy. Simple perhaps, but effective. 

To put this song in its proper cultural tradition, one must look back to the absurdist radio program the Goon Show. This song isn't supposed to be interpreted on a symbolic level, its simply a heartwarming song about friendship and a life without worries.
comment_183: As a kid when I went to the beach,  and gazed intently at the sea, the waters would appear  to be green. I am not sure whether green means money alone because there is plenty of greenery in nature, or what is left of it. Incidentally, I  still recall watching waves, small ones like ripples lap into the  shore from various angles, different directions. Whenever they collided I always thought they would   sort of crash and disintegrate,  but I was surprised and thrilled to find that they would always merge and reemerge and continue along their course  as if nothing had happened. A wave is first and foremost not just an abstract trigonometric or periodic function,  but a real physical entity with a crest and a trough, although math can hope to capture and model some characteristics or aspects of it,  to the extent possible,  but just by remembering what I saw,  I can say with absolute certainty, the waves in reality  neither know about nor care to obey the law of the integral of Fourier series.

I think it's about doing acid. It sounds childish because when you're high you act pretty childish. Clever, eh?

Anyways, here is my dissection of the song:

"In the town where I was born, 
Lived a man who sailed the sea"

This line refers to the dealer.

"And he told us of his life, 
In the land of submarines."

He's telling them about his experiences on acid. 

"So we sailed on to the sun, 
Till we found the sea of green"

This line's about dropping acid til you're on a trip

"And we lived beneath the waves, 
In our yellow submarine."

When you're high your troubles, or 'waves' are away from you.

"We all live in a yellow submarine, 
Yellow submarine, yellow submarine"

"And our friends are all aboard, 
Many more of them live next door"

They're saying how they're dropping acid with their friends.

I'm not sure about this line. Maybe it refers to the fact that when you're high you appreciate music.

comment_235: It's not that complicated. It's a psychedelic novelty song, and they're just having fun with all the sound effects and noises and stuff. The drug part: someone was high and experienced depersonalization; he experienced his body as a vehicle for moving about in the environment and his consciousness as a person (living) inside of it - and then generalized it to 'we'. That's where the refrain came from. The verses are just some folk-y seafaring lines to fill out the song. Really, it's that simple. Whether you like it or not is another matter. At least consider the context.

comment_237:
Ok, as always, my own interpretation. Please do not judge me for my views, as this is the main fact that makes it worth while for us all to be on here and it leaves a slight distaste to one who is negatively critisized.

Charles Manson was released from prison on 21 Mrach 1967. You have to have a bit of background info on Chralie, as they called him, to understand many of this, but C believed that there would at some stage, rather sooner than later in his time, be an uproar of racial differences in the US. (Long storie Short). 

When he was realeased he returned back to the ranch where himself and (Some call them his followers). It was the second ranch where they found refuge and it was called the Spahn Ranch or something like that.

Manson was adiment to start his own little town/city in the desert, and was sure that this would be a place where they all could survive in peace, when the civil war broke out. They could exist in such a darrn place, where no one else would be able to survive, not knowing how to. they started to accumulate all needed to build their city and Manson's plan was to create incredible music, aiming to be signed and recorded, to help fund his dream of having his own perfect city.

They practised, wrote lyrics, put songs together and became perfect at what they were doing. Eventually, as they felt they were ready, they set off to LA, to be discovered. (Keep in the back of you minds that, Beatles released their WHITE album in this time period, I think just before 1967.It was said that Manson was very influenced by them and that most songs on the WHITE album, was a direct communication from the beatles to himself and his followers.Manson sort of denies this though and said that it was some of his family that began to unravel the hidden messages in the songs) 

Manson was acquainted with some guys in the music industry and his plan was to get in touch with one of them and they could arrange from there to be sampled in studios to perhaps record etc.
His main contact was out of time, when himself arrived in LA, but he was surprised to find out that the labell was speaking about them, but could not reach them, due to their desolate residence on the Spahn farm in the desert. 

Charlie then set out to find a place of residence for a short while, while they waited for this friend of him to return. (I think his name was Dannis) They needed a big enough place to house about 15 to 20 people and it needed to be close enough to where all the shit was going down in the industry they were so desperatly trying to break into. They found a house in Gresham Street, in Canoga park. About 30mins drive from hollywood and only a couple of miles away from the ranch. IT was quite spacious and guess what. The house was bright yello and had submarine like windows on the top floor. Get this, Charlie actually christened the house "The Yellow Sub-Marine". As they stayed there and became known, many guests would visit the house. At one stage the Beatles were often found, visiting the house. They would stay there at Charlies place, when in that part of the world when doing shows etc. 

The house was described as a place that drew you in. You could go in so easily, but a week might quickly pass before you come out again, as you get so caught up in, not only the drugs , but the lifestyle that was reigning with it. charles was believed to have an incredible strong mind and motivational/manipulating qualtities. Charlie woud say that "The family would remain 'submerged' beneath the awareness of the outside world"

This my dear friends, was the yellow submarine that the beatles wrote about. 
 - Budokan
